{{Year nav topic2|1981|television|radio|film}}<!--no space 1981--> The year '''1981 in television''' involved some significant events. Below is a list of [[television]]-related events in 1981.
''For the [[United States|American]] TV schedule, see: [[1981-82 American network television schedule]].''
== Events == * February 20 â [[Comedian]] [[Andy Kaufman]] ruins sketches and starts a brawl live on the air during [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]]'s ''[[Fridays (ABC TV series)|Fridays]]''. * March 6 â After a 19-year run, [[Walter Cronkite]] resigns as head anchor of ''[[The CBS Evening News]]'' and is succeeded the following Monday by [[Dan Rather]]. * June 30 â [[Fred Silverman]] is fired as president of NBC, after failing to improve that network's third-place standing, and is replaced by [[Grant Tinker]]. * July 4 â [[Showtime (TV network)|Showtime]] ends its part-time status and inaugurates a 24/7 schedule. * April 11 â [[Van Halen]]'s lead guitarist [[Eddie Van Halen]] marries ''[[One Day at a Time]]'' [[actress]] [[Valerie Bertinelli]]. * August 1 â The [[MTV]] network debuts on [[cable television]], playing [[music videos]] 24 hours a day. * September 21â25 â is the week when [[soap opera]] [[supercouple]] [[Victor and Nikki Newman]] first meet each other on ''[[The Young and the Restless]]''. * November â ''[[The Doctors (1963 TV series)|The Doctors]]'' airs its milestone 5000th episode. * November 2 â American [[soap opera]] ''[[As the World Turns]]'' debuts a new opening sequence and [[theme song]] for the first time in its 25-year history. * November 8 - [[ESPN]] televises its first live flag-to-flag [[NASCAR]] race, the [[Atlanta Journal 500]]. * November 16 and November 17 â [[Luke and Laura]]'s wedding on ''[[General Hospital (US TV Series)|General Hospital]]'' becomes one of the most watched weddings in American television history, second only to the wedding of Charles, Prince of Wales and Lady Diana Spencer. * December 25 â [[Chuck Woolery]] hosts his last episode of ''[[Wheel of Fortune (1975 US game show)|Wheel of Fortune]]'' after a salary dispute with show producer and creator [[Merv Griffin]]. [[Pat Sajak]] takes over as host the next Monday, the [[December 28|28th]]. He hosts the daytime ''Wheel'' till 1989.; Sajak hosts the nighttime ''Wheel'' to this day. * [[Berlinda Tolbert]] and [[Michael Jonas Evans]] makes their final appearance as [[Lionel Jefferson|Lionel]] and Jenny Willis Jefferson in the seventh ([[1980-81 American network television schedule|1980â1981]]) year, of ''[[The Jeffersons]]'', also departing with Tolbert and Evans, [[Paul Benedict]] makes his final appearance as the [[England|British]] neighbor of [[George Jefferson|George]] and [[Louise Jefferson|Louise]], Harry Bentley, Benedict returns to the series in [[1983 in television|1983]]. * November 9 â The cast and crew had begun work on episodes for [[The Incredible Hulk (TV series)|''The Incredible Hulk''{{'}}s]] fifth season on [[CBS]] when the network's head of programming, Harvey Shepherd, delivered a surprise blow: despite maintaining solid ratings, ''The Incredible Hulk'' was to be canceled immediately. Author Frank Garcia, while interviewing Johnson, learned that CBS executive Harvey Shepherd disliked ''The Incredible Hulk'' and felt that there "wasn't a full season left in it", thus putting an end to David Banner's struggles. Producer [[Kenneth Johnson (producer)|Kenneth Johnson]] tried to convince Sheppard to buy six additional episodes so that CBS could have a half-season of new episodes but he declined. The series was canceled so suddenly that Johnson never had a chance to film an INCREDIBLE HULK series finale which would feature David on trial for the murder of Elaina Marks. Several scripts including "David Banner, RIP", and "Killer On Board" never went before the cameras to become small-screen Hulk adventures. The notice came so quickly and so suddenly that Johnston and Corea were unable to film a proposed two hour finale in which David was brought to trial for the murder of Elaina Marks. Production officially halted in the summer of 1981. * During the course of the year, all [[soap operas]] produced by [[Procter & Gamble]] change title sequences and theme songs. ''[[Another World (TV series)|Another World]]'', ''[[Guiding Light]]'', ''[[Search for Tomorrow]]'', and ''[[The Edge of Night]]'' all have new title sequences.
